text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.18.4, Distribution, Knowledge Services.

IRM 1.18.4.4.1, Alternative Media Center (AMC) products, new items added to reﬂect taxpayer notice program, Multi language section, and how to order accessible notices for employees and Taxpayers. Added Large print to list of products requiring conversion.
IRM 1.18.4.4.2, Alternative Media Center (AMC) services, added ITM course 70110 to curriculum. Added Accessibility helpline to list of AMC services.
IRM 1.18.4.4.3, Alternative Media Center (AMC) Accessible taxpayer notices and letters, Updated taxpayer notices section to give guidance on how to obtain IRS notices in preferred alternative media
Update organizational information.
Follow required document formatting, including Internal Controls and Material Changes.
Reorganize the IRM after adding or removing any substantive content.
Adhere to Plain Writing requirements.
This update supersedes IRM 1.18.4 dated January 25, 2021.
Media and Publications (M&P) employees
Table of Contents
Audience: This IRM is for the Knowledge Services employees who provide services to all Publishing and Distribution electronic systems and applications.
(1) We use the following acronyms throughout the IRM.

Requirements Integration (

) BRSI section responsibilities include: • Information Technology Budgeting • Information Technology Application Development and Program Manage- ment • Computer Assisted Publishing System (CAPS) Management • Enterprise Logistics Information Technology (ELITE) Management •
tensible Markup Language (XML) Support • Uniﬁed Work Requests (UWR) Submission Processing • IRS.gov Help Desk Comments Processing Technology (

) BRSI analysts manage the IT budget for CAPS and ELITE in the Media and Publications (M&P) organization. In this capacity, they: a. Gather and monitor IT requirements b. Meet with management to review IT requirements and budget

Information Technology Budgeting Information Technology Application Development and Program ment Computer Assisted Publishing System (CAPS) Management Enterprise Logistics Information Technology (ELITE) Management
tensible Markup Language (XML) Support Uniﬁed Work Requests (UWR) Submission Processing IRS.gov Help Desk Comments Processing
BRSI analysts manage the IT budget for CAPS and ELITE in the Media and Publications (M&P) organization. In this capacity, they:

c. Work with appropriate IT organizations, Technology Integration and Project Support (TIPS), and M&P division technology advisors to ensure that IT requirements and budget needs are properly communicated and that funds are available for annual maintenance costs and new purchases (

) They work closely with members of other organizations (e.g., Procurement, Accounting, IT) to resolve IT issues and problems using a combination of spreadsheets and online applications (including the IT Project Tracking System (PTS), Work Request Management System (WRMS), and the Invoice Process- ing Platform (IPP)) to ensure requirements are funded and requisitions are processed timely. (

) BRSI analysts provide IT solutions to serve the business needs of the M&P user community. They collaborate with business representatives to collect data and manage business, functional, and technical requirements. The analysts identify and resolve application issues and monitor the progress of all applica- tion development. BRSI analysts use the CAPS M&P IT Request and Work Request systems as communication tools to facilitate these tasks. (

) BRSI analysts coordinate application software procurements for the M&P orga- nization, including new software and services, and ongoing maintenance contracts for existing components. The analysts submit Uniﬁed Work Requests (UWR) detailing necessary updates to IT via WRMS for tracking and coordina- tion purposes. BRSI analysts create requisitions in the Invoice Processing Platform (IPP) and prepare any required supporting documents. (
) BRSI participates in and provides oversight for Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) activities for GSS-
(CAPS-I) and ELITE. This includes facilitating meetings with various IT business units, Cybe

ecurity, system development and test team members for the Security Assessment and Authorization certiﬁcation process. BRSI ensures compliance with FISMA re- quirements that includes: a. Planning for system security b. Reviewing and monitoring the security controls on a regular basis c. Participating in system security testing annually d. Developing and maintaining action plans for remediation of security weaknesses (

) CAPS hosts locally-developed and Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) software applications that support the design, composition, requisitioning, printing pro- curement, and job tracking for all IRS published products. These include the Core Repository of Published Products (CROPP), the Electronic Publishing website at http://www.publish.no.irs.gov , and “Page
,” which is a group of M&P intranet pages. (

) BRSI analysts manage CAPS, including database and application software maintenance and administration. IT Enterprise Operations provides operational support for CAPS hardware and system infrastructure software (including in- stallation, upgrade and maintenance, security administration, and monitoring). (
) Contractors perform most of the technical work on CAPS. BRSI contracting officer’s representatives (CORs) provide support and oversight for the contract work performed. Services

(1) BRSI analysts manage UWR submissions from M&P to the IT organization by:
Receiving, reviewing, and validating completeness of submissions Providing assistance to M&P initiators Pre
coordinating requests with IT and W&I TIPS Submitting UWRs in WRMS Tracking the status of submissions to ensure timely responses are provided to IT

KRM designs, develops, tests, implements, and promotes tools to foster knowledge collection and sharing. The tools include:
(3) KRM uses knowledge management expertise to provide M&P with tools to promote a knowledge-sharing environment and helps other M&P functions by:

b. Collecting lessons learned c. Interviewing management-selected current and departing employees d. Developing process maps e. Training new M&P employees on the tools and techniques of Knowledge Management (KM) f. Consulting on KM activities throughout the organization g. Researching and implementing other techniques as appropriate (

) KRM solicits and analyzes submissions from M&P employees for knowledge- sharing topics, derives and drafts knowledge articles for sharing on the M&P knowledge management website, and provides expertise and assistance regarding social collaboration. Center (
) KRM section employees administer the M&P resource center Shar
oint site at https://organization.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/wi-care-MP/default.aspx in collabora- tion with site administrators in M&P business units. This Shar

oint site con- tains descriptive documents and references that M&P functions use in collaborative efforts throughout M&P and affords collaboration and repository functionality amongst all M&P functions. IT manages the Shar
oint infrastruc- ture (servers), provides governance policies and standards, and resolves cation issues. (
) KRM leads a team of Shar

oint site administrators that includes one or employees from the Distribution, Publishing, and Tax Forms and Publications functions of M&P. This team recommends and implements overall site policies and enforces adherence to IRS Shar

oint and Web standards. Each site ministrator manages their function’s sub-sites, Web content, and document libraries within their organizational and program boundaries, and the KRM collection administrator retains responsibility for the M&P Shar
oint site homepage and other cross-organizational M&P content. (

) Administration responsibilities include: a. Create, populate, and maintain user groups b. Manage user access rights (e.g., granting and revoking user inclusion policy groups during temporary assignments and revoking access rights for separated employees) c. Collect, analyze, and report on Web statistics d. Troubleshoot and resolve user issues and elevate to the IT Help Desk when appropriate e. Respond quickly to website outages and work with IT to restore Web access f. Analyze and respond to user requests for Shar

oint objects, such as sub-sites, custom lists, and document libraries g. Probe and resolve broken hyperlinks h. Provide and control access to the DSTEST development and test envi- ronment i. Analyze, test, approve, and launch custom Web functionality j. Respond to inquiries directed to the team’s e-mail box; *W&I Map Share- Point Admin at wi.mp.sharepoint.admin@irs.gov k. Apply and manage appropriate site features to address user business quirements (Shar
oint site settings) (

Content responsibilities include:

a. Solicit or develop fresh content for announcements on the M&P Resource Center homepage b. Develop and manage content for the main M&P site, collaborating with the Planning and Analysis branch of M&P c. Develop and manage content for the M&P Career Services site, collabo- rating with the employment specialists in the Strategic Planning and Analysis offices of each function d. Develop and manage content for specialized content on other M&P sub- sites that cross organizational boundaries e. Develop and maintain keyword searches for site collection (

) The site collection administrator, a KRM section employee, also has other duties in addition to the content and administration duties listed earlier. Those additional duties include: a. Represents M&P on IRS Shar
oint governance forums b. Serves as liaison to W&I Shar

oint nonexecutive councils c. Maintains website collection registration d. Manages site collection quotas and obtains Web resources from IT as appropriate e. Maintains overall site design to preserve standardization, usability, and consistency throughout the organization f. Collects, analyzes, and reports on overall Web usage and other statistics g. Ensures that function site administrators have appropriate training in Shar
oint and Section
accessibility issues and provides coaching and assistance (

) KRM analysts use a content management application to administer Web content on IRS.gov for Distribution at https:// www.irs.gov/forms-instructions in their roles. Working with creators/publishers and page stewards across the division, KRM analysts manage Distribution content to ensure the information is technically correct, remains current, and is updated timely or removed as appropriate. They also work with Online Services Web analysts and Content Area Administrators from other business units as needed to revise or remove content. Detailed guidelines, procedures, roles, and responsibilities for Wage Investment (W&I) Internet content management are maintained in IRM
, Internet Content Publishing Process (ICPP) Management Document. (

) The Knowledge and Resources Management (KRM) section provides a point- of-contact (POC) for the Publishing and Distribution functions for questions relating to content pages on IRS.gov. A W&I POC listing is on W&I’s Internal Content Publishing Process (ICPP) page at http://win.web.irs.gov/icp/wi_icp. htm . (

) Any IRS.gov website user can submit an inquiry about the website by email, telephone call, or Web chat to the IRS.gov Help Desk (Help Desk). An inquiry can be a question, problem, or comment regarding the Web content and IRS programs. The Help Desk answers most inquiries received from the public within
hours. (

) When an inquiry reaches the Help Desk, KRM checks it against a repository known issues, e.g., pre-recorded (pre-determined) responses and Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs). KRM escalates inquiries the Help Desk cannot address to the W&I IRS.gov POC.

Note: KRM forwards tax account-related inquiries that require interpretation of tax laws and procedures to the appropriate IRS function for response.

a. The POC determines which subject-matter expert (SME) within W&I would be the most appropriate party to answer the questions and nates a response timeframe b. The Help Desk determines the priority and designates a response timeframe c. The W&I POC forwards the email to the identiﬁed SME for response d. The SME answers the inquiry and sends an e-mail back to the POC, formats the response and sends it to the Help Desk with a copy to W&I organization mailbox e. The W&I POC keeps a copy of the e-mail in the personal folder The AMC provides alternative media resources to IRS employees and taxpayers through publishing support for format selection, acquisition, tion, and dissemination of IRS products required in accessible ﬁle formats. The AMC offers more than
alternative media formats of IRS published products. The items produced are a combination of public-facing and non- public-facing products.

nates a response timeframe The Help Desk determines the priority and designates a response timeframe The W&I POC forwards the email to the identiﬁed SME for response The SME answers the inquiry and sends an e
mail back to the POC, who formats the response and sends it to the Help Desk with a copy to the W&I organization mailbox The W&I POC keeps a copy of the e
mail in the personal folder
Note: Non-public products include all items listed in public products.

In the future, addition languages may be provided. Staff produces alternative media products in both electronic and hard copy formats through:

Compliant PDF Files • Program

-S: Braille Products • Program

-S: Braille Products (Ability One Program) The AMC operates a production facility using high- speed embossers and printers to process Braille and large print orders. The facility is an on- demand operation that serves employees and taxpayers. In addition, AMC employees perform ﬁle management for these formats on multiple systems and applications including Enterprise Logistics Information Technology (ELITE), Account Management Services (AMS) and the Electronic Status Notice (ESN) to ensure uninterrupted distri- bution of accessible media through mainstream channels
AMC products can be ordered by employees and taxpayers.
Products Available to Employees and Taxpayers

• Download accessible media from the Prod- uct Catalog Information page at http:// publish.no.irs.gov/catlg.html • Visit the Order page at http://amc.enterprise. irs.gov/order.html on the AMC intranet site • Contact the AMC Helpdesk at altmc@irs.gov • Use the Order and Subscription anagement System (OSMS) at https://caps-as. enterprise.irs.gov/osms/views/hom
age.xhtml • Order Braille and large print tax products through the AMC annual survey • Notices in alternative formats.
The IRS process for receiving notices allows visually impaired taxpayers to request post-ﬁling tax correspondence in Braille, large print, audio (mp
) or electronic formats. This includes notices about additional taxes or penalties owed.
Taxpayers with a print disability can elect to receive IRS correspondence in their preferred alternative format by completing Form
, Alternative Me- dia Preference , and ﬁling it with their tax return, or by mailing it separately to the following address:

Who can order... How to order... Taxpayers • Download accessible tax products from the Accessibility pages at https://www.irs.gov/ forms-pubs/accessible-irs-tax-products on IRS.gov • Request paper copies of Braille or large print tax products by calling the tax form toll- free telephone number at 800-829-3676 • Notices in alternative formats 1. The IRS process for receiving notices allows visually impaired taxpayers to request post-ﬁling tax correspondence in Braille, large print, audio (mp3) or electronic formats. This includes notices about additional taxes or penalties owed. 2. Taxpayers with a print disability can elect to receive IRS correspondence in their preferred alternative format by completing Form 9000, Alternative Me- dia Preference , and ﬁling it with their tax return, or by mailing it separately to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Kansas City, MO 64999-0002
(4) AMC products are delivered based on the following turnaround times.

Product Deliverable Timeframe Braille and large print products (in production facility are embossed/printed ) 7 to 10 business days Electronic ﬁles Immediate download Products Requiring Conversion • Accessible HTML • Accessible MS Office ﬁles • Braille and e-Braille • Section 508 compliant PDF • Text • Large Print • 4 to 6 weeks • up to 10 business days • 4 to 6 weeks • up to 10 business days • 2 to 4 weeks • up to 10 business days

The AMC provides the following services: a. Accessibility Help Line - IRS established an Accessibility Helpline to answer questions related to current and future accessibility services tax information in alternative media formats (i.e. Braille, large print, etc.) available to taxpayers with print disabilities. Taxpayers who need accessibility assistance can call

Assistance for multilingual taxpayers is also available on the helpline via the Over-the-Phone Inter- preter service. The new helpline does not have access to taxpayers’ accounts. Those needing help with tax law, refunds or other account- related issues, should visit the Let Us Help You page b. Customized accessibility solutions - The AMC works one-on-one with customers to meet their individual accessibility needs c. Document Accessibility consulting - The AMC works with employees to ensure their electronic content is accessible by people with disabilities and meets the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) and Section
standards d. Helpdesk services - The AMC Helpdesk staff is available to assist employees Monday through Friday from
AM to

PM ET by e-mail at altmc@irs.gov . Employees can place orders for alternative dia, inquire about the status of orders or get technical support for making electronic content accessible. All incoming requests are assigned a number and placed in a contact management database for tracking pur- poses e. Review and remediation for Section
compliance - The AMC can make PDF ﬁles accessible for people using assistive technology and review and add accessibility to Microsoft Office ﬁles including Word, Ex- cel and Powe
oint. The AMC works with employees to review and re- mediate electronic content to meet the requirements in the WCAG and Section
standards f. Training and tutorials - The AMC provides Ho
ube videos and training tools for authors in the Learn section on the AMC intranet site at http:// amc.enterprise.irs.gov/. IRS employees can also take the following courses in the AMC Section
curriculum on the Integrated Talent agement platform

Web Services - IRS employees can visit the AMC intranet site at http:// amc.enterprise.irs.gov/ to request services, order alternative media and learn about the latest accessibility requirements, including tools to make electronic content compliant with Section 508.
The Accessibility pages at https://www.irs.gov/forms-pubs/accessible-irs-tax-products on IRS.gov pro- vide taxpayers with accessible tax products in the following formats:
• Section

-compliant PDF ﬁles • Braille (e-Braille) and text tax forms, instructions and publications • Large print forms, instructions and publications • HTML format for tax instructions and publications • e-Pub format to view tax products on mobile devices
format to view tax products on mobile devices (

) IRS employees can request these services using the following methods: a. Visit the Request Section at http://amc.enterprise.irs.gov/request.html the AMC intranet site b. Contact by email the AMC Helpdesk at altmc@irs.gov . (
) Taxpayers can complete Form

, Alternative Media Preference PDF, to choose to receive their IRS tax notices in Braille, large print, audio or elec- tronic formats. This includes notices about additional taxes or penalties owed. Taxpayers can include the completed form with their tax return, call
, or mail it as a standalone form to the IRS at the Address below to request their preferred format. Department of the Treasury - Internal Revenue Service - Kansas City, MO

) If the taxpayer already received a notice or letter in print format and prefers in Braille, large print, audio or text, choose one of the three options below request your preference. a. The taxpayer can call the tax assistance number at
b. The taxpayer or Customer Service Representative can fax the notice a cover sheet to: Alternative Media Center, at

On the cover sheet, write ″ Alternative Media Format ″ at the top and include payer’s name, address, daytime phone number and preferred alternative media format c. The taxpayer can mail their notice with a note stating their preferred format (Braille, large print, audio or text) to: Internal Revenue Service, Alternative Media Center,
N.
th St. Room G
, Richmond, VA
) Once the AMC receives your notice it will take up to
business days to convert it to your preferred format and mail it back to you. (

) The AMC uses a variety of marketing and communication strategies to perform outreach, promote accessible tax products and develop partnerships with ability organizations to better understand taxpayer preferences. (
) Utilizing social media allows the AMC to provide continuous information to taxpayers about the accessible tax products available on IRS.gov. (

) Building relationships with advocacy groups who support people with disabili- ties and the aging population keeps us informed of their needs and allows us to share information.

Once the AMC receives your notice it will take up to 15 business days to convert it to your preferred format and mail it back to you.
